ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Recent literature on epistemology. I found nuanced but constructive positions such as contextualism and warranted direct realism personally most helpful in navigating questions on justification and knowledge.

A good sense of the major topics in Epistemology (which are kind of unintuitive and would probably be hard to learn on your own), as well as a better general understanding of how contemporary analytic philosophy is done. That is, even though I'm not super interested in Epistemology, taking this class made me a much better philosopher because it provides a unique insight into how philosophical theories and cases interact (and contrasts with ethics in that 99% of the time you go with the cases, not with the theory), and also spent significant time talking about philosophical methodology and meta philosophical debates about intuitions and whatnot.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The conversational-style lectures were excellent, and I particularly enjoyed the memorable insights and drawings.

Sheets are somewhat disorganized, but theyre easy to follow if one keeps up with the readings and lectures.

Strengths: 
1. Very thorough coverage of the topics covered
2. 3 short essays + 2 exams + final paper gave lots of opportunities to practice writing and get feedback
3. KDR rightly assigns a lot of his own work, which makes the class very interesting since you get to see how a philosopher engages with the rest of the field, and you can ask him questions about his positions and stuff.

Weaknesses:
1. Sometimes feedback was a bit short and uninformative
2. The expectations for the 2 exams were a bit vague. It was unclear whether the focus should be on reconstruction or on forwarding your own idea, and the short time frame (especially for the midterm) made it difficult to accomplish both

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes to those who want to dive into the basics of epistemology and some approaches in modern philosophy. Definitely a yes for those interested in religious epistemology.
Yes, I would highly recommend if you're interested in doing modern analytic philosophy.
